title: National and State Planning in India

information.title: Historical Context
information.description: India adopted a planned economy model post-independence, with the establishment of the Planning Commission in 1950 to formulate Five-Year Plans.

information.title: NITI Aayog
information.description: In 2015, the Planning Commission was replaced by NITI (National Institution for Transforming India) Aayog, which serves as a think tank and fosters cooperative federalism.

information.title: Functions of NITI Aayog
information.description: NITI Aayog designs strategic and long-term policies and programmes, provides relevant technical advice to Centre and States, and serves as a platform for resolution of inter-sectoral and inter-departmental issues.

information.title: State Planning
information.description: States have their own planning boards or departments that work in coordination with NITI Aayog to formulate state-specific development plans.

information.title: District Planning
information.description: The 74th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1992 mandated the creation of District Planning Committees for consolidating plans prepared by Panchayats and Municipalities.

information.title: Annual Plans
information.description: With the discontinuation of Five-Year Plans after the 12th Plan (2012-17), the focus has shifted to annual plans and three-year action plans.

information.title: 15-Year Vision Document
information.description: NITI Aayog is tasked with preparing a 15-year vision document in tandem with global Sustainable Development Goals and India's unique needs.

information.title: Sectoral Approach
information.description: Planning in India follows a sectoral approach, focusing on key areas like agriculture, industry, infrastructure, social services, etc.
